item.title: Fuel issues persist in south but 'over' elsewhere
item.description: Petrol problems are "virtually over" in Scotland, northern England, and the Midlands, say retailers.

item.title: Milan plane crash: Eight dead as private jet hits building
item.description: It took off from Milan's Linate airport, but came down soon after and hit an empty building.

item.title: Conservative conference: UK in period of adjustment after Brexit, says PM
item.description: Boris Johnson refuses to rule out supply problems at Christmas as fuel shortages continue.

item.title: Emily Ratajkowski alleges Robin Thicke groped her on Blurred Lines set
item.description: Emily Ratajkowski alleges Robin Thicke grabbed her breasts while filming the hit song's music video.

item.title: Church sex abuse: Thousands of paedophiles in French Church, inquiry says
item.description: A commission finds evidence of 2,900-3,200 abusers within the country's Catholic Church since 1950.

item.title: Afghanistan: Several people killed by bomb attack near a Kabul mosque
item.description: The attack happened as a prayer ceremony was being held for the late mother of a Taliban official.

item.title: Full power ahead for UK to Norway under-sea power cable
item.description: The 450-mile cable connects Blyth in Northumberland with the Norwegian village of Kvilldal.

item.title: Bernard Tapie: French tycoon, 78, died peacefully, his family said
item.description: The businessman, politician and sports club owner was one of France's most recognisable figures.

item.title: London Marathon 2021: Race attracts 80,000 participants
item.description: An estimated 80,000 people run the London Marathon in the city and virtually via an app.

item.title: Sarah Everard murder: We'll stop at nothing to jail more rapists - PM
item.description: Boris Johnson also says women should have confidence in the police after the murder of Sarah Everard.

item.title: Andy Burnham: I'm not after Starmer's job
item.description: Greater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham says he is not going after the job of Labour leader, Sir Keir Starmer.

item.title: Severed finger's owner traced by police in Southampton
item.description: The 28-year-old man, who lost part of his finger while climbing a fence, is being treated in hospital.

item.title: La Palma: New eruptions from the island's volcano
item.description: Two new vents are causing further eruptions from the Cumbre Vieja volcano on the island of La Palma.

item.title: 'Girls are very much involved in exploitation in gangs'
item.description: An ex-gang member turned exploitation consultant explains the role of females within a gang structure.

item.title: Shropshire sheep sold 11 times at same charity auction
item.description: The Charollais ram was put up for resale repeatedly, raising £7,000 for two charities.

item.title: The American father and son building a Gothic folly in France
item.description: Donald Russell, 94, and his son Sam are building a Gothic-inspired edifice in the French countryside.

item.title: ICYMI: An eerie sculpture and quintuplet cubs
item.description: Here's a look at some of the stories you may have missed this week.

item.title: Knife Crime: Should police post pictures of knives online?
item.description: Campaigners say posting such photos on social media accounts does more harm than good.

item.title: Elephant Man dissection: 'Joseph Merrick would be heartbroken'
item.description: Disability campaigners including Adam Pearson oppose an Elephant Man dissection show.

item.title: 'Speedo Mick' asked to leave Cornwall pub for being underdressed
item.description: Mick Cullen, who walks in swimming trunks, is told he cannot stay "dressed like this."

item.title: The pioneering Scots photographer who captured China
item.description: John Thomson spent a decade during the 19th century capturing images from all walks of life in the Far East.

item.title: Bringing a centuries-old craft back to life in County Tyrone
item.description: Glass-cutting in County Tyrone was once world-renowned, and the craft in the area dates back to 1771.

item.title: Windermere climber completes 83 ascents in two months
item.description: Anna Taylor, from Cumbria, climbed routes listed in Ken Wilson's renowned guidebook Classic Rock.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Rape case sparks fury over China's work drinking
item.description: As public scrutiny of corporate misbehaviour grows, can business drinking be dropped forever?

item.title: What climate scientists can teach us about dealing with climate change doom
item.description: Climate anxiety is on the rise, so we spoke to climate scientists about what helps them deal with feelings of hopelessness.

item.title: Budget Ukrainian airline swaps high heels for trainers
item.description: Flight attendants with Ukraine's SkyUp say the new uniform is much better for their health.

item.title: Shortage problem: What's the UK running low on and why?
item.description: Shortages are one thing we don't seem to be running out of in the UK right now.

item.title: In need of modernisation? The UK’s housing crisis close up
item.description: Thousands of people are saving to get on the property ladder - but not everyone who gets on it is a winner. Five stories from the UK’s ever-changing housing market.

item.title: Analysis: Met facing questions over Everard murder
item.description: There is an air of crisis in British policing this weekend as it faces a great moment of reckoning.

item.title: Conservatives: Who funds them, and what's in it for them?
item.description: To be in the top 10 of Conservative donors, you're going to need a seven figure sum.

item.title: Paris attacks: Haunting survivors' memories shake terror trial
item.description: The harrowing, personal, stories of people caught up in the 2015 attacks take centre stage in Paris.

item.title: How healthy are vegan ready meals?
item.description: Vegan alternatives have never been more widespread, but are they a healthier option?

item.title: Torquator Tasso shock 80-1 winner of Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe
item.description: German outsider Torquator Tasso is a shock 80-1 winner in the 100th running of Europe's richest race, the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe.

item.title: Tottenham 2-1 Aston Villa: Hojbjerg finish and Targett own goal give Spurs much-needed win
item.description: Tottenham produce their best league display since the opening-game win over Manchester City to end a run of three straight league defeats with victory over a stubborn Aston Villa.

item.title: Watford sack manager Xisco after 10 months in job
item.description: Watford sack manager Xisco Munoz after 10 months in the job, with the club saying "recent performances strongly indicate a negative trend".

item.title: Jepkosgei and Lemma win London Marathon titles in rapid times
item.description: Joyciline Jepkosgei takes world-record holder Brigid Kosgei's London Marathon title as the full-scale race returns.

item.title: Highlights: Suarez scores as Atletico beat Barcelona
item.description: Watch the highlights as Luis Suarez scores against his former club, Barcelona, to send reigning champions Atletico Madrid level with Real Madrid at the top of La Liga.

item.title: Match of the Day analysis: Did resting Ronaldo backfire for Man Utd?
item.description: Match of the Day's Gary Lineker, Ian Wright and Danny Murphy debate whether Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's decision not to start Cristiano Ronaldo cost Manchester United against Everton.

item.title: Travel update: When do the green and amber lists change?
item.description: Eight countries have now moved from the UK's red travel lists, to the less restrictive amber.

item.title: Stamp duty holiday: How much do I have to pay now?
item.description: Stamp duty rules are changing in England and Northern Ireland.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Long Covid: What is it and what are the symptoms?
item.description: Significant numbers have had long-term problems after recovering from the original infection.

item.title: Covid passports: How do I get one and when will I need it?
item.description: People in Scotland will need to be fully vaccinated to go to clubs, sporting events and concerts.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The progress made in vaccinating the country's population, as almost 49 million people have received at least one dose.

item.title: What is redundancy and what are my rights?
item.description: If you've lost your job, here is a guide to your financial entitlements.

item.title: COP26: What is the Glasgow climate conference and why is it important?
item.description: A crucial climate change summit is being held in the UK - this is why it's important.

item.title: Climate change: Is the UK on track to meet its targets?
item.description: With a month to go until the UK hosts a global climate summit, is the government on track to meet its own commitments?

item.title: Pakistan: How to cool Karachi as temperatures rise
item.description: In Karachi, Pakistan, one entrepreneur is on a mission to plant urban forests to cope with rising temperatures.

item.title: How climate change is making inequality worse, especially for children
item.description: Children will face up to three times as many extreme climate events as their grandparents, research suggests.

item.title: Female Afghan judges hunted by the murderers they convicted
item.description: Six former female judges who have gone into hiding speak to the BBC from secret locations across the country.

item.title: Xianzi: The #MeToo icon China is trying to silence
item.description: A court has thrown out a high-profile sexual harassment case. Can China's feminist movement survive?

item.title: Covid debt: A baby, job loss - and now eviction
item.description: Tenants are being evicted due to rent arrears built up during the pandemic, an investigation finds.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'In my business, you eat what you kill'
item.description: Music executive Riki Bleau shares his business advice for our CEO Secrets series.

item.title: The torso in the Thames: A 20-year mystery
item.description: Twenty years ago, a young African boy was murdered and his torso was dumped in the Thames. It's the longest unsolved child murder case in the recent history of the Metropolitan Police.
